sentence: Voters go to the polls this November to decide whether Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump will be the next President of the United States.
Many experts view Hillary as the more moderate candidate with positions that mimic her husband, Bill Clinton, and the current president, Barack Obama.
A Clinton administration is also believed to be less detrimental to the market and economy than her counterpart, Donald Trump.
Regardless of which candidate you prefer, it would be wise to consider what themes and sectors should be watched closely if Clinton is elected to office.

On the campaign trail, the presumptive Democratic nominee has said she plans to crack down on turmoil in the Middle East and hold China accountable in the territorial dispute over the South China Sea.
Her resume as Secretary of State and former member of the Senate Armed Services Committee suggests she will be more aggressive than Obama when it comes to military spending.
Aerospace and defense companies are likely to be the biggest beneficiaries with Northrop Grumman (NOC) and Lockheed Martin (LMT) as the two front runners to acquire the top U.S. defense contracts.
Meanwhile, the firearm industry typically surges under a democratic leader.
The fear of gun control pushed by the liberal left often causes surging gun sales and share prices.
Smith & Wesson (SWHC), which has skyrocketed lately, should continue to grow at a rapid clip.
Clean energy is the bread and butter of any Democrat’s platform and Clinton hasn’t been any different.
Her campaign pledges to install 500 million solar panels by 2020, roughly 7 times the current capacity.
This would be a big boost for the solar industry which has otherwise struggled this year.
SunEdison recently filed for bankruptcy after failing to restructure its enormous debt.
SolarCity’s (SCTY) future is also up in the air.
The company continues to burn cash at such a clip that its now looking for a bailout from Tesla (TSLA).
Clinton has been a staunch supporter of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) and has said that she would expand coverage to the 30 states that currently do not participate.
Increased coverage would benefit sectors in the healthcare industry such as hospitals and managed care providers.
Aetna (AET) is one of the companies in line to flourish from wider Medicare and Obamacare coverage.
That said, a Clinton presidency won’t be good for the entire sector.
Pharmaceuticals and biotechnology are in for a rude awakening give, her stance on drug prices.
She has frequently stated that drug companies need to be held accountable for jacking up costs.
Despite a few exceptions, Silicon Valley is overwhelmingly behind Hillary Clinton.
The list of endorsers include business executives from Facebook (FB), Google (GOOGL), Salesforce (CRM) and Netflix (NFLX).
Liberals are typically more progressive when it comes to technology.
Clinton’s plan to improve the tech space involves creating new opportunities for minorities to gain funding and postponing student debt for startup employees.
Diversifying the workforce would generate an additional $500 billion in new value and boost GDP as much as 1.6%.
Clinton has also called for higher standard in regards to digital threats.
Cyber security is predicted to be one of the biggest threat to our well-being for the next 5 years.
Any improvement to increasing our protection would provide a meaningful boost to the cyber security industry.
The presumptive Democratic nominee has had a hard time gaining the trust of voters, but her position on key issues aren’t likely to significantly sway the market.
Her proposed policies would have the biggest impact on sectors such as defense, energy, healthcare and technology.
Regardless of who wins, investors would be wise to maintain a long term focus even if that means missing a quick buck.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
